PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan ("RMP") in December of 2020 as a result of planned changes to the facility's existing Isopentane Intermodal Transfer Covered Process, and to revise various RMP data elements that have changed since the previous plan update submitted in May of 2018.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:



- Adding Mixed Pentane Blend Intermodal Transfers from Rail Cars into ISO Tank Containers at an existing RMP Covered Process, which previously applied only to Isopentane Intermodal Transfers.  n-Pentane represents a new regulated flammable substance present in the Mixed Pentane Blend to be handled at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  



- Removing Vinyl Acetate Monomer ("VAM") storage in Stolthaven Houston Tank P40-1 from the RMP. VAM is no longer stored and transferred from this tank.  



- Removing Mixed Pentanes Direct Transfers performed between Rail Cars and Marine Vessels from the RMP. This operation is no longer conducted at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal. 



- Updating the Offsite Consequence Analysis worst-case release scenario and the alternate-case release scenarios for regulated toxic and flammable substances handled at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal based on a refined modeling and process analysis completed in November of 2020. Previous Offsite Consequence Analyses were conducted using the less detailed RMP*Comp platform. 



- Updating the facility's Emergency Contact name and information. 



- Updating the maximum on-site inventories for all 4 RMP regulated chemicals, and  



- Various RMP data element updates based on revisions to Stolthaven Houston's Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") found in the terminal's Local Training Manual ("LTM").





? 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is committed to operating and maintaining our processes r

elated to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  The facility uses a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees and assets, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding community.  This Executive Summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has designed and implemented, including:



- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68 that may be handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities.



- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs.



- A five-year history of significant accidental releases, if applicable, from processes covered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") RMP regulations



- An overview of our emergency response programs



- An overview of completed and planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring, and



- Detailed information about our Risk Management Program





? 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. owns and operates a bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 188 above-ground storage tanks that vary in capacity from 2,000-barrels up to 110,000-barrels, five truck loading/unloading racks (Truck Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6, and T-8), four rail car loading/unloading racks (Rail Racks R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-5), one dedicated barge dock (Barge Dock-C), a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths used for handling barges and ships (Ship Dock 2/3), and a new jetty placed into service in October of 2019 for handling barges and ships (Ship Dock 11).  A rail

car cleaning and intermodal transfer station (Rail Rack R-4 and Truck Rack T-7) is also located within the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and a biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are operated on-site to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's operations on the environment.



Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo container including tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston, Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate storage in the facility's above-ground storage tanks.  Similarly, land-based intermodal ("IMO") transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.



The following chemicals handled at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause off-site consequences in the event of a significant accidental release:



Regulated Toxic Substances Currently in Storage:



Toluene Diisocyanate ("TDI"), Mixed Isomers: Chemical Abstracts Service ("CAS") Number 26471-62-5

Vinyl Acetate Monomer ("VAM"): CAS Number 108-05-4





Regulated Flammable Substances Handled via Intermodal Transfers Only (Rail Cars into ISO Tank Containers):



Isopentane: CAS Number 78-78-4

Pentane Blends (Co

ntaining up to 95-Percent n-Pentane): CAS Number 109-66-0





TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Isopentane and Pentane Blends containing up to 95-percent n-Pentane are periodically transloaded directly from rail tank cars into ISO tank containers with no intermediate on-site storage, other than loaded rail cars received into the facility that are staged on the terminal's storage tracks prior to performing the transfer into empty ISO Tank Containers.  As a result, Isopentane and n-Pentane are not always present above their respective threshold quantities at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.



Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment during the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.



TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. currently stores TDI in one 30,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D30-10) and in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks (Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D15-19 and D15-22).  Tank D30-10, which represents the facility's worst-case toxic release scenario, has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 13-million pounds (1,291,497-gallons).  Tank D15-19 has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 6.4-million pounds (626,258-gallons).  Tank D15-22 also has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 6.4-million pounds (625,944-gallons).  TDI is received into the facility via delivery by marine parcel tankers, tank trucks, and rail tank cars; TDI is shipped outbound from Stolthaven Houston, Inc. by rail tank cars and marine parcel tankers.  Periodic

direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. with no intermediate product storage in the three referenced D-Tank Farm storage tanks.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has over 26-years experience in the safe storage and handling of TDI. 



As part of the changes associated with additional TDI storage in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D15-19, significant modifications were performed such that TDI is handled safely and efficiently in this tank, including installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell, installing a line constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing marine dock line in D-Manifold used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers, replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D15-19 system with ball valves for ease of operation and automation capability with an actuator, installing a stainless-steel pump for TDI at Storage Tank D15-19, installing hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D15-19 while in TDI service, insulating Tank D15-19, installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing, installing electric heat tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral line to D-Manifold, installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen, and installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D15-19 vapor line prior to TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header to reduce the concentration of TDI in the vapor system.  Full automation for D-Tank Farm is expected by the end of 2020. 





ISOPENTANE & PENTANE BLEND INTERMODAL TRANSFERS



Isopentane and Pentane Blends containing up to 95-percent n-Pentane are periodically transloaded directly between rail tank cars spotted at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-

2 into ISO tank containers located at Truck Rack T-6, with no intermediate product storage in any of the terminal's storage tanks.  Vapors generated during these intermittent transfer operations are directed to the Tank Farm Vent Flare for vapor control.  Loaded rail cars are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and are held on the facility's storage tracks before being moved to Rail Rack R-2 to perform the product transfers into empty ISO Tank Containers that have been pre-purged with Nitrogen and spotted at Truck Rack T-6.  Note that after loading, the ISO Containers are weighed and immediately transported off-site by tractor-trailer.  Maximum chemical inventories reported with this RMP update for Isopentane and n-Pentane conservatively assume that six rail cars loaded to 31,500-gallons of each cargo are held simultaneously on the facility's storage tracks.  During calendar year 2019, 55-separate Isopentane IMO loading events were completed between Racks R-2 and T-6.  The newly proposed Pentane Blend IMO transfers using the same equipment used during the existing Isopentane IMO transfers are projected to commence in December of 2020.







VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS



Storage Tank P50-5 is an existing internal floating roof ("IFR") tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,445-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16.5-million pounds (2,118,691-gallons).  Tank P50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case VAM release scenario, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers, and occasionally by barges, that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges into rail ta

nk cars with no intermediate product storage, and VAM slops can also be received into the terminal from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston's docks.  



In November of 2017 Stolthaven Houston placed IFR Storage Tank P50-4 in VAM service.  Tank P50-4 has a working capacity of approximately 48,651-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 15.9-million pounds (2,043,337-gallons).  As a result of the 2017 VAM storage project for Tank P50-4, piping modifications were completed in P-Manifold to connect the marine transfer system for Tank P50-4 into the existing Dock Line 78 already in place for Tank P50-5 and dedicated to VAM service.  A new VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to Storage Tank P50-4.  



Note that the Tank P50-4 VAM storage project did not change the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's worst-case release scenario for VAM, as the maximum quantity of this material held in any one tank did not increase; existing IFR Storage Tank P50-5 continues to have the largest inventory of VAM in storage.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water if-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has over 11-years experience in the safe storage and handling of VAM. Stolthaven Houston plans to fully automate P-Tank Farm in the coming years.  





   

? 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:



- Process Saf

ety Information ("PSI")



- Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA")



- ISO 9001:2015 Certified Quality Management System ("QMS")



- Employee Training / LTM



- Mechanical Integrity Program



- Spill Containment and Countermeasures



- Management of Change ("MOC")



- Pre-Startup Safety Review ("PSSR")



- Vapor Control Systems



- Compliance Audits



- Formal Incident Investigation



- Employee Participation Program



- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits



- Departmental / Safety Meetings



- Trained Emergency Response Team ("ERT")



- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors



- Mutual Aid Membership



- Ongoing Automation Enhancements and Upgrades



The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent, and respond as needed, to accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.





? 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the preceding five years there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal that resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO Certified QMS to identify the root cause of the event, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.





? 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Stolthaven Houston maintains a Facility Response Plan ("FRP") with the United States Coast Guard, Houston-Galveston Sector. Our emergency

response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC").  Stolthaven Houston's hazardous chemical inventory report (i.e. Tier II report) is maintained current with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality ("TCEQ"), the North Channel LEPC, and the local Channelview, Texas Fire Department.  Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is also a member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid ("CIMA"), which can provide world-class, rapid response assistance in the event of an on-site emergency.    



An Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personnel injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.   





? 68.155(f):  CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The following is a list of completed and planned/ongoing initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, to protect company employees and the environment, and to effectively manage hazards present at the facility:



- A new role, Emergency Response Coordinator, was created and filled to the streamline the terminal's training and response efforts in the event of a significant incident at the facility.



- As they are made available when empty and clean, storage tanks with the potential to store toxic and/or flammable liquids are being equipped with quick-closing ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of ongoing safety enhancements and automation efforts, which include status alarms displayed in the terminal's 24-hour Operations Control Room, and remotely actuated valve closures.  Complete automation of D-Tank Far

m and associated systems is expected by the end of 2020.  Complete automation of P-Tank Farm and associated systems is expected by the end of 2024.  



- Automated valves installed on lines at Truck Racks and Rail Racks.



- Double verification of all line and hose connections before commencing any product transfer operations to reduce the possibility of incorrect valve/hose alignment.



- Adding a concrete secondary containment floor and total organic carbon ("TOC") analyzer to the facility's A-Tank Farm.  A-Tank Farm is one of Stolthaven Houston's original Tank Farms, and was originally constructed with earthen secondary containment.  



- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001:2015 Certified QMS.



- Employee Experienced Feedback Program.



- Fall protection added at transfer racks where trucks and ISO containers are loaded and unloaded.



- Two new 753-horsepower each fire water pump driver emergency diesel engines added in 2019 at new Ship Dock 11 for fire fighting response.  



- A personnel temperature scanner installed as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. 



- Gas detection systems updated in 2020 to include 5-gas monitors with photo-ionization detectors ("PID").



- Fire fighting equipment upgrades in 2021, including the purchase of a new Fire Truck and a utility terrain vehicle ("UTV") Quick Attack Unit.



Additional capital budget projects under consideration for future improvements to safety and emergency response at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. include additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's east expansion property, and adding concrete paving to four existing tank farms (B, F, S, and Q) that currently have earthen floors to improve both secondary containment capability and surface working conditions for employees.
